Just to be clear, this 1 star is here only and exclusively due to the fact that this game costs 2x what Gloomhaven costed me, and while I could forgive a few faults then, when the game was new and Isac (the creator) didn't have the funds to make everything perfect, there's simply no excuse for the faults anymore;

Simple fact is that I've paid 250€ for a game, which comes with inserts made of THE WORST fragile plastic imaginable. Aldi meat is packed in a higher grade plastic box. This is beyond ridiculous. The damn thing, despite the box not having any apparent damage, came warped and is very much, obviously so, unable to support the game pieces. I'd forgive it with a small, cheaper game, but 250€ for THE WORST damn quality materials is unforgivable. Did they have to cut every damned corner and cut every damn cost while charging us the damn game's weight in silver?!

And since when is it even acceptable, that games -can- ship in such a state, and we're expected to, and it's perfectly normal to everyone, that we have to fork over another 100+€ for inserts, just so I can play the damn thing.


EDIT 1:

After playing this game for a while it becomes apparent that this really is just an expansion of Gloomhaven. It's more of the same, BUT with some extra mechanics tagged on that really don't justify themselves.

The drop in quality (alongisde a massive price hike) is also egregious. The map, for instance simply no longer aligns with the stickers (the default or the removable extra pack, which you have to buy as an extra addon!). The seams of the map don't align with the sticker cuts so they all look displaced on an already busy map or they fold and come off the map when you fold the map itself.

So far, there's been disappointment and annoyances alongside "simply more Gloomhaven", but at worse quality.

Update: I don't lightly rate games a 1. I really have to not like a game to be given that. Even games I don't care for end up as a 2 or a 3. I have tried week after week to like this game. I just don't. It's actively making me dread my wednesday game nights. I'm 21+ scenarios in which is like 65-80 hours. It's eaten up months of my precious game nights. The characters are not fun, the scenarios are long and drawn out. The turns where you miss are obnoxious. The turns where you get locked out of doing anything is annoying. Enemies have shields/flying or retaliate. It's like fuck me, this sucks to attack anything. Your hand becomes weaker and weaker. The characters I've played have all been "micro-manage the boardgame". Items are less useful and far too expensive. You don't share anything with others you're banding with. The story is boring and verbose. The town phase is just too much. I just do not like this game. I'll still play Gloomhaven (possibly, although this is starting to sour me on xhaven), but once we're unfortunately done with the campaign since the other 3 players like it, this is going in the trash. It's not replayable and I don't want anything to do with this.

I'll try to keep this super brief. Basically it's Gloomhaven on steroids. There is more to do, more scenarios, more monsters, more in depth characters, etc. That's all super cool.

HOWEVER...jesus fucking christ is there too much shit in this box. If you thought Gloomhaven was bad, this just cranks it up to an 11.

Characters - Fun concepts, but far, far, far more fiddly and less interesting than previous ones.

Story - Eh, Gloomhaven was pretty disjointed, but this feels overwrought and uninteresting. Like they hired more writers, but it just becomes tedious and uninteresting after a few paragraphs. Nothing really sets the stage.

Monsters - Again, fun, but why include like 4-6 different types on maps to just snag one or two for scenarios? Like it's a waste of time to have to find each one, open the bag, shuffle the deck, find the card, organize it, randomize the token, etc. It's just too much.

Obstacles, Token, Etc. - It's just an avalanche of pieces and each one is different and you'll need three of them, oh, but it's in a different compartment, oh, but we moved it over there because there is no room on the table. How many did we need? Where do they go? Which book are you looking at? AHHHHHHHHHH!

The legacy part of this is also frustrating. Too much can't really be undone and it becomes incredibly hard to play with another group. I really wanted to like this more than I have. It's got some cool concepts, but none meld together and too much shit in every sense of the word.

I'd so much rather play Oathsworn each time over this. Even the base game of Gloomhaven I still very much enjoy. This just doesn't work for me even if some of it I like while others just feel like bloat.

Too little, too late.

Also, Jaws of the Lion proved that Gloomhaven should be streamlined, not upscaled. Too much game.

Probably the most disappointing experience of my adult life. We loved Gloomhaven so were really looking forward to this. Unfortunately the many flaws mean it has overall not been a fun experience.

The biggest issues are
1. The story is extremely poorly written to the point it essentially doesn't exist. The actual writing content is bad, like a 12 year old wrote it, the pacing is appalling. We find out about the big bad 3 scenarios from the end, which isn't even really an end. It doesn't have an ending.
2. It is designed for 4 players and is not well balanced if you have 2 players. Several scenarios we had to replay over on a lower level but could clearly tell with 4 players it would have been trivial, either because monster spawn hit points or movement didn't scale correctly with character count.
3. Special rules. I get it, kill all monsters got a bit dull in gloomhaven. But special rules for the sake of it often became like managing a small accounting firm.
4. Randomisation of events doesn't work well. We didn't have the first town guard upgrade until 3 scenarios from finishing and didn't have the trial deck until the last scenario. What's the point in having functions that you don't get to use unless replaying scenarios?

Ultimately we didn't play the final scenario because it looked like a nightmare to set up and manage and we didn't want to. The game had ground our spirits down so far we just gave up and read the conclusion after over a year of time invested into it. And that conclusion was meh. What has been the point.

Frosthaven is an evolution of Gloomhaven and I'm not sure I like it's new form. It feels much more of a chore to play through and a lot of the new elements start off feeling novel but soon become rote and repetitive. The settlement phase is a prime example with most people just zoning out, looking at their phones or letting out an audible sigh when we have to go through this part.

This also feels much more semi cooperative than Gloomhaven with everyone doing their own thing with the only real interaction is through tripping someone up, them taking the thing you need or getting in your way.

The loot game is also a step backwards; coins were great in Gloomhaven as you could use them back in town to purchase new items. Now, everything you pick up is trash and making you feel more like a garbage man than an adventurer.

Rating it a 3, but it's a very split rating.
The underlying mechanics are still good, and in fact have been slightly improved from Gloomhaven (which I gave a top rating to), making it a great tactical skirmishing RPG thing. The new character designs are often complex in unnecessary ways, and there is an over reliance on placing overlay tiles which makes it harder for many combinations of characters to play together due to competing over the resource of featureless hexes. In Gloomhaven we generally couldn't wait to play the new characters, but in Frosthaven that is a relatively rare feeling. My adult group hems and haws, not really finding them enticing, with one player reaching back to pilot a Gloomhaven class as none of the available options are interesting to her. At home with my children it's no better, one of them is playing her second Gloomhaven class in Frosthaven, and the other is planning to play a Gloomhaven class next, despite our having 5 unplayed unlocked classes. We have only 4 classes left to unlock at home, and I doubt that those last 4 will be much more enticing.

Story is slightly improved, the lore is a bit better.
The new method of unlocking characters is poorly done, and the new outpost phase is a slog that I'd skip given the chance. Splitting the resources/loot into several types of material and also many herbs introduces unnecessary variance in what your mercenaries might have; one group of mercenaries in my home game had an excess of hides but a continual lack of metal, while in another game at a friend's house we have very balanced material resources, but have one specific herb that we never seem to find. Why not just use coins and exchange them for need materials?
Two huge frustrations are the inability to tell a story with any foreshadowing, and the puzzles.
For the foreshadowing, I am referring to the plot, the character unlocks, and the events.
Events (road, outpost, etc.) Still mostly fall back on the Gloomhaven standard of "pick A or B, but you can't really tell which will be the good result"; some events now use the character traits on cards (e.g., strong, persuasive, etc.) And where this works it does feel better, like you have correctly interpreted the message (some foreshadowing, Yay!), but these events are not common, and sometimes use the "wrong" attribute. One example suggests that I've option might be to convince the NPC of your plan or something, which sounds clearly like the "persuasive" trait would be helpful, right? Wrong! Isaac expected you to threaten them, even though that isn't implied anywhere on the card, so the correct trait is "intimidating".
This lack of foreshadowing extends to many of the class unlocks, which may make sense in hindsight, but are otherwise random.
But by far the worst aspect of this game are the puzzles. The reaction to the puzzles in Gloomhaven was from what I saw largely negative, with people exasperated at having to do a crazy amount of sitting symbols in card art it hidden on the map to unlock a bonus, but at least it wasn't required. You could skip it and not really notice anything lacking from the game. In Frosthaven, Isaac doubles down on puzzles, making them a required part of the campaign. The puzzles are poorly designed for the most part, the best of these being a simple cypher to decode. Others are as nonsensical as the puzzles in Gloomhaven, with no built in hints. Having introduced the calendar, Isaac could have added a hint system overtop of the puzzles (add xxx.x to the calendar in 3 weeks, this is a hint on the puzzle you just started) but instead there is nothing to advance things. A game like pandemic legacy does this repeatedly - if you don't have the previous bit solved and wouldn't be able to advance, plot events catch you up.

The puzzles are frustrating, I'm trying to avoid "spoiling" them, though it is very generous to assume that any appreciable portion of players will enjoy them. They ruin a game that was among the most enjoyable otherwise. I'm only about 2/3rds of the way through the puzzle book, but each one I find makes me more angry with the crappy puzzles we are meant to solve. I would not play this game again, and will likely not buy any follow up. I think Isaac developed a really neat game engine and is a good designer of mechanics, but is not a great story teller, and is a horrible puzzle designer. The fact that an escape room owner weighed in on Reddit about how badly these puzzles are done is exactly the point.

As a huge fan of Gloomhaven, I was surprisingly heavily disappointed by Frosthaven! To set the stage: we've played through almost all Gloomhaven scenarios + Expansion + Jaws. We usually played at +1 difficulty with leaning to +2 at higher characters levels. We love challenge! However, Frosthaven feels under-tested, not challenging. We faced too many moments that could be easily fixed by proper testing! Unfortunately, the game became a chore at some point that it became difficult to convince everyone to continue playing. Here are some details:
- Gloomhaven was always a complicated game, but Frosthaven is over-complicated. The complexity comes out of nowhere. We use the app (Secretariat) which is fantastic! But the complexity comes from rules where the app can’t help us. Instead of making rules easier to understand and more logical, developers added even more rules which override each other. For example, “empty” hex is now a complex mechanic which consists of “feature-less” hex and “figure-less” hex. Even though, we completed Gloomhaven, we often found ourselves not knowing how to resolve a situation. The amount of time we use Google/BGG/Reddit to check details is ridiculous.
- Class mechanics are unnecessary complex for some classes and very easy for others. Even worse, the class balance is all over the place. On top of that, playing many classes is frustrating. All you do is wait until the perfect moment to finally use your basic mechanic. Indeed, GH didn’t have the perfect class balance either, but I don’t remember such huge gaps between characters.
- What makes it worse is the change to starting level of new characters. You can start at a level equal to 1/2 prosperity (opposed to 1=1 in GH). Therefore, we had level 1 characters at the same party as level 7 character. Together with poor class balance, it adds to frustration.
- Too many scenarios have long special rules. It’s nice to have an additional spark to “kill them all” but having half a page explaining additional effects is too much. I mean, it’s fun having such effects once in a while but FH is full of it. On top of that, most of special rules sections are badly written and counter-intuitive. We had to Google almost every scenario with special rules to understand nuances.

Overall, I can’t recommend purchasing Frosthaven. At least, not until the 1st revision (2nd printing). The game requires thorough playtesting. If you’re new to X-haven games, get Gloomhaven! It is still complex, deep and interesting game!

I loved Gloomhaven and really liked JoTL. While FH has made some improvements, the whole package is a significant step down. Biggest complaints:

- The puzzles in the puzzle book are mostly awful and gate game progression so you can't just ignore them. If someone hadn't posted hints on reddit, this game would have been tossed in a bonfire months ago.
- Yes, the puzzles are worse than Forgotten Circles (though slightly less intrusive)
- The classes for the most part just feel like work instead of fun.
- Some of the classes feel so limiting that certain scenarios are likely impossible with the wrong combination, which sucks b/c those scenarios may gate retiring/replacing those characters.
- Did I mention the puzzle book?
- While I do like the addition of the town building, with the combination of the characters being more complex, the sessions times seem overly long.

Not likely to play "Frosthaven" ever again. Maybe if someone else owned it and was willing to host a series of game nights and make sure the game was set up before I arrived and do all the bookkeeping so I didn't have to.

"Gloomhaven" was already a beast with too much fiddling and too little game. "Frosthaven" turns the fiddling (set-up, tear-down, bookkeeping) up to 11, and turns down the gameplay.

It's now much faster and easier to retire characters... but that's not a good thing. I want to get attached to a character and keep them around for a while.

I don't know... "Frosthaven" exhausts me just thinking about it. I think "Gloomhaven" and especially "Jaws of the Lion" are superior games, and I never mustered the fortitude to slog through the entirety of "Gloomhaven". "Jaws of the Lion" I did complete, and have played with multiple groups. I know I would never finish "Frosthaven" even if I wanted to.

If what you're really after is more "Gloomhaven" check out the amazing fan expansion, "The Crimson Scales", instead.

Scenario design especially has moved away from Gloomhaven’s strengths—Kill All Monsters scenarios with few or no special rules continue to be significantly better than other scenarios, but there are a lot fewer of them this time.

If this had come out before Gloomhaven it would have been the best thing I’d ever played, and my views may yet change with time, but two steps forward, eight steps back leaves a bad taste in the mouth.

EDIT: we’ve played 98 scenarios thus far. The number of very scenario mechanisms suck the fun right out of the game. Long ago we decided to skip them entirely and forget the campaign. We also completely ditched the town building and defense. Now we just play the scenarios in order, skipping the super-fiddle ones.

I’ve also house-ruled potions and amount of items that can be carried. So we have a small deck of cards as we close in on Level 9 of our 4th characters — and THAT is FUN!! (We also upped the level for the enemies.)

Update
We decided to sell our game after being 18 scenarios in.

You will definitly love the game, if you played and enjoyed Gloomhaven.

Also this game does nothing wrong directly. I might have another perspective if I were 20 years younger, but I'm lacking the luxus to replay 4h scenarios multiple times, because I have managed my card play a little bit wrong and get exhausted a few moves before the scenario is done.

Also I had the feeling that at some point the game wants us to fail and just go to collect some ressource multiple times, before being able to progress.

As a result, we started bending the rules at some point and tried to find workarounds around the game mechanics.

But that makes the whole thing pointless at some point.

The rating, reflects, that the game does not actually do that much wrong, but it's just too much of everything and I probably wouldn't necessarily want to play it anywhere anymore.

It lacks however some love... For the inserts, for the organization, the materials tend to bend a bit, the board starts to become somewhat loose, stickers for the rulebook you cannot remove a millisecond after hitting the smallest point of a page, lack of story (compared to other campaign games these days its a joke). There is no love in this game. It was designed from head, but not from passion.

I really dislike the changes they made to this game, and some of the promised but undelivered items (like the Map Book used in Jaws of the Lion instead of the map tiles).

Comparing to the OG Gloomhaven, you'll be grinding more for resources to actually craft your town AND weapons AND items. It's an alright mechanism but this could be handled digitally via companion app instead of actually stickering resource cards. What I hate is that money/coins is WAY harder to come by, and so far after going about 50% of the game there are less than 4 sticker upgrades we made to our class cards. You will also be using money for multiple things making it a very necessary resources that (I guess) is thematically hard to come by as thematically nobody cares about money in the frozen wastes EXCEPT it's required...it's as if it's somehow dangerous to give players resources and let them be used and have the players have fun.

The classes are more boring in this edition, and there are less "strong" classes, as in they are more balanced, but I'd rather see classes be a bit more specialized in what they do rather than balanced. Just my 2 cents. Also after playing Gloomhaven fully, and then Jaws of the Lion, and now Frosthaven I am quite tired of the design choices and mechanisms in this game. The encounters also feel...similar but that's it's hard to make 70ish missions feel mostly special or memorable. Still, I'd rather replay Gloomhaven fully then start another Frosthaven campaign.

A better game mechanically, but If you're bored of gloomhaven this won't change your mind. Gloomhaven was ultimately broken once you got the hang of it, but the fun, like literally any rpg ever made, was in learning how to break it. Frosthaven has so thoroughly filed off all the exploitable edges that there's few exploits left to discover for yourself. This game feels like a job now.
It's the same problem rpg video games and even dnd now have, where they've been ruined by the Internet spilling their secrets. Instead of employing the man spamming class guides on the subreddit, they should have gagged him.

There's still conceptual darling classes like the geminate that are wildly OP once you realize the gimmick is not actually any kind of restriction.

Needs more wacky map effects, you should be building a rube Goldberg machine of scenario hazards and slippery ice and spike traps. The new balance seems to discourage you from cheesing the map layout, which is the most fun to be had in this combat system. Every other enemy seems to be flying now. In terms of visual clarity the map tiles are a huge step down from gloomhaven, what is ice/snow/bluestone is impossible to tell. What is hazardous/trap/difficult is extremely unclear and even the meaning of any piece of cardboard constantly changes between scenarios.

New chaff based loot mechanics remove the last bit of dopamine. Oh boy, a wooden plank for christmas.

The map and calendar and vehicles and all that, cool, add half an hour more cardboard and sticker admin each session. Honestly playing dnd would be less work.

Frosthaven feels incredibly more difficult with 2 players. Some of the starting characters should not be starting characters - some are too antisynergistic with each other that 2 players are forced to optimize their characters instead of playing what they want.

I have never felt disheartened playing gloomhaven - even after failing a scenario, however unlikely - I cannot say the same for frosthaven - failing scenarios - changing characters - and failing the same scenario again - the game does not seem optimized with 2 players in mind - and that's okay for some people - but not for this review.

But still a good game. I'd play it again.

We’re on year two of playing this. For the most part, we're still enjoying it. For the majority of the combat mechanics, character cards (enhancement), and the like, it improves on most of the things we struggled with in Gloomhaven—notable exception: Oozes, which still ruin scenarios on a regular basis—but a few of the changes left us scratching our heads.

The biggest wins are in the characters, who feel a bit more balanced than Gloomhaven, and their thematics. We originally enjoyed how unlocking characters is story-based, not retirement based (with the retirement bonus turning to buildings for the Outpost)—but that lost its charm a year or so into playing when we still hadn’t unlocked half the new characters.

The setting feels more "alive," and having a stake in our own settlement helped grounding us more than in Gloomhaven. The loot system of using a deck, and crafting, has us more invested in picking up loot than before, as well—looting is way better than just coins.

Alas, crafting started off weak and slow and it might be our character choices, and potions were even worse. It’s the equivalent of RNG, but our journey through unlocking potions (which is entirely random based on the ingredients you manage to loot) was absolutely painful. It took forever for us to end up with a healing potion (and we were unlocking whatever we could, just never had the right combos).

The encounter cards split into season and road/outpost make for a more immersive experience, and while we've only bumped into a couple of scenarios where we've hit a wall (again, Oozes are still broken, and we're houseruling them twice over: waiting for both their shuffle cards to come up before shuffling them, and just copying damage on new spawned split oozes). We’ve also started playing on "Easy" which still feels difficult depending on our quartet of characters (the "closest character gets pummelled by massive number of attacks on round one" problem).

On the downside, the iconography on the cards is sometimes less intuitive (push and pull, for example), and multiple tiles are so close to each other it's frustrating looking for the right ones (cave "door"?). The time-per-session is was raised by the extra steps of the Outpost phase, which isn't inherently bad, exactly, but does sort of put a tedium tone to things after finishing a scenario, so we decided to skip it one session and then began playing with the Outpost Session as our starting point, and then playing a Scenario and stopping once we’ve finished the scenario (so, basically, we "finish" the previous scenario before we start a new one, then leave the Outpost Phase to be handled again next time).

One really sore point is—as we're playing with four players—the incomprehensible limit of two of each craftable item, especially the potions, which meant only two of the four of us can have any type of item. We're making them with ingredients we find ourselves. How can we only make two of each? It makes zero sense (and yes, I get the real-world reason: it would mean more cards) but I’d rather have had less options but enough cards to actually equip four players.

Added to this is the frustration of playing a new character after retirement with the slower scale of levelling via Prosperity—when our first character retired, the other three characters were level four, but even at Prosperity 3, my retired character meant I'm had to play a level one character, who routinely got one-hit-knocked out/required discards due to low hit points. Gloomhaven allowed characters to start at a level equal to or lower than the Prosperity level, but Frosthaven slows that down to half the Prosperity (rounded up) which meant starting at level 2 didn't happen until Prosperity 4… which was a long time coming.

Finally, "masteries" are obnoxious. If you've got a player who loves the challenge of trying to earn their masteries, prepare to have a frustrating experience of their character making very sub-optimal choices while they try to earn that extra checkmark doing things that make little-to-no sense. It's like an extra-frustrating Battle Goal, only far more tedious to watch unfold.

Edit to add: Bumping this down from 8 to 7 to 6. Having now played through the game for two years in real world, and entering year three of the game (we just started our third Summer), our four-player group has hit consensus that the "problem" of Frosthaven is mostly in how much more complicated everything feels on a scenario basis—far less "Defeat all enemies" (which wasn’t a broken situation) and quite a few more "here are the scenario goals" (which feels like fixing something that wasn’t broken).

It's by no means as bad as Forgotten Circles was, but—for example—Scenario 71 where there are *seven* enemy types, three of which use one battle deck while fighting the other four as well as the players, during an escourt mission, with summons happening on odd and even rounds and... Each round of combat took ages to figure out. If we hadn't had one of the unlocked classes with a particularly good one-two combination of cards to grant movements to allies, it would have taken at least another hour to play, we estimate, and could easily have ended for naught in a failure. Basically, when we see "Complexity Three" rank for a scenario, we find ourselves groaning in anticipation of much less fun, and a lot more "okay, wait, what happens this round?"

Further Edit to add: We’re on our third year of playing this, and we’re at the point now where we’re skipping it as many weeks as we’re playing it, because we have to be very much in the mood for the frustration that comes with so many of the scenarios, and add to that the puzzle book and… honestly? If it weren’t for people online, our entire group would have just given up. The puzzle book is *awful*, and it gatekeeps the story from concluding. Paths are locked until you use the puzzle book. Don’t like badly designed (and error-inclusive) puzzles? Then you’re done with Frosthaven unless you go seek out spoilers online. Worse, and especially if you—like us—generally only play, say, a scenario a week or every other week or so, these puzzles become even more unsolveable. As a not-so-random example, the clue you need for the solutions to one of the puzzles is in the concluding text of a scenario we played *two years ago*. Why would we remember that? The puzzle book alone has tanked this experience for us—its inclusion might be great for people who like escape room style puzzles, but if you don’t and were enjoying Gloomhaven and Jaws of the Lion, surprise! Frosthaven includes impenetrable puzzles now.

They should have worked better to include more unique overlay tiles that are more visually distinct so it is easier to set up each scenario and easily know at a glance the meaning of each.

Frosthaven is what everyone that played and finished a campaign of Gloomhaven wanted, but not in the way they wanted it. Context: My group has played and finished absolutely everything Gloomhaven. We're talking games, expansions, fan campaigns and semiofficial scenarios, as well as full fan campaigns. We have poured 3000-4000 hours into this game system. So, that said, what about Frosthaven which we've mostly completed throughout?

Frosthaven has a huge amount of fluff on top of a structure that didn't need it, crafting that requires flow charts to understand, a base building system which works narratively but ends up being very uninteresting gameplay wise and adds extra logistics on top of a 3-4h dungeon session. Classes that are more complex and dense to play but that feel much too hard to play well, for the same benefits you'd get playing a classic Gloomhaven class moderately well.

I've been struggling to find enjoyment in some classes and you need to play them for about 12-16 scenarios to complete the personal scenarios... about 30-60 hours. Some feel very complicated for no real upside, others just don't feel good to play, if you played the original Gloomhaven, the triangle class is the closest to the experience of Frosthaven.

The town phase has promise, but if you're even moderately successful you'll never see any of the supposed narrative story engine happening. There generally won't be any highs and lows in fighting off baddies in the Winter season or any rush to prepare the town in the safe Summer season. The various shops and places seem somewhat random as to when they appear given how they're unlocked and we've felt we've wanted some much earlier than we got them doled out. In the end, all this does is tack on 30 minutes to a game that didn't need it.

The scenario system having a chart mode is really useful but also it misses the point of WHY anyone wanted to 'chart' the scenarios in Gloomhaven to begin with... you'll go into a scenario, if you play even 3-4 times a month, you can have NO clue what it's about, as the last time you've done the chain was four months ago. The flowchart doesn't adress that problem of needing a 'previously on'. The game allows you to go very wide in a quite sandboxy way, and you can get lost in a ton of misc scenarios and chains and chains which are LOCKED behind just.. playing other scenarios/waiting for them to tick down. The game still fails to provide a consistent narrative experience as much or harder than even Gloomhaven did. There's argueably one main 'act 1' and one 'act 2' main quest chain, which each have exclusionary 'choice' scenarios, and one very long chain that takes you all across the game, and that's sort of it. There are of course some other smaller 2-3 quest chains but it all feels somehow less but also more. There are enough scenarios, just that they kind of fail to provide some of the really organic narrative developments that Gloomhaven could do.

Scenarios themselves now seem to each have half a page of 'special rules' you need to read for them. Very few end up with a simple 'kill all the dudes' or 'loot the thing' or 'push two levers'. Each scenario has you relearning new mechanics, which often are described quite mechanically, and we'd be trying to figure out what the designer was intending to happen in the mission to be able to interpret how the rules would work. There's floating driftwood used as barges, sometimes working one way, othertimes another way, there's various pillars doing various effects in various ways or moving around the map or having special mechanics, monsters spawning in in different configurations at different spots on the map on odd or even or both types of rounds and some don't spawn past a round while others spawn indefinitely... it all felt very tiresome by the half game mark. Opening a scenario and seeing a big purple text block was just frustrating when maybe we just wanted to focus on the tactical challenge instead of figuring out how to play tiles that are elevator levels going up or down as you climb up a shaft.

Frosthaven is Gloomhaven turned to 12, not to 11, just overcharging it and making everything run stronger, but 12, going past overcharging right into blowing out the engine. It may be the right amount for some people, but i feel for some it might leave them entirely behind and cold.

I don't regret my time with Frosthaven, i just wish that now that we've 'gone big' we'll teeter back to a more condensed and focused experience with whatever's new. I really consider Jaws of the Lion struck a perfect balance of a moderate but heavy experience and not overstaying its welcome, as well as a better narrative by having the players be guided more thoroughly. Gloomhaven could also get long in the teeth and had its own batch of issues (fixed in 2nd edition mostly). But i wouldn't recommend Frosthaven to anyone else but people that have gone HARD and played all of the Gloomhaven games already.

What I do like is how this game unlocks its characters compared to Gloomhaven. Rather than drawing a random character whenever you retire a PC, you unlock them over the course of the campaign in a more organic way. You made friends with a certain tribe? Congratulations one of them wants to join you. The retirement conditions are also a lot more reasonable compared to the first game, which is a godsend.

In short it improved on one of the weaker portions of the first game (recruitment and progression). However, it over compensated in regards to inventory, city management, and novelty.
